prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
AITA for resenting that my children see their mom as a hero?
My ex wife is a perennial fuck up. She’s been to jail on numerous occasions, had several affairs, lost more jobs than I’ve ever had, and currently lives with her mother. I was a single dad for three years to three children, years where I learned to braid hair so I could care for my daughter. I’ve remarried, and my wife and I provide the children with everything. We pay for their healthcare. We help them with their school work. We sign them up for activities they are interested in and take them to those activities. We pay for those activities. We help them with their school projects. My son is almost 16, and we will buy his car. My eight year old daughter needs braces, and we will pay for them. I ask their mother for no child support because she can’t even support herself. I don’t wish to hurt her. In fact, I’ve forgiven her for who she is and what she’s done. 
Fast forward to tonight: my daughter is entering a pageant. We’ve paid for the dress. We’ve paid the entrance fee. She gets me ask her questions she might be asked at the pageant. One was, “Who is your hero and why?” 
My daughter says, “Do you think I should say, ‘my mom?’”
I said, “ You realize you have family here? We provide for you. We registered you for this pageant. We attended the meeting. You live here full time. We care for you and love you. I know that you get to go to your mom’s every other weekend, and you have no chores there. You eat whatever you like (mom has food stamps), but it’s easy to be a parent two weekends a month. It’s harder to be a parent all the time.” 

I’ve never derogated their mother. I don’t want to cripple their image of her, but it’s frustrating as hell that they see her as this angel and don’t appreciate everything their stepmother and I do for them. 
"""

Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let's try to figure out if the author is in the wrong here. So, the situation is that the user is a stepfather who's been taking care of his children since their mother, who has a problematic history, couldn't. He's now remarried, and they provide for the kids financially and emotionally. The issue comes up when his daughter is preparing for a pageant and might say her hero is her mother.

The user is frustrated because the kids see their mother as a hero despite her issues. He's not directly badmouthing her but is pointing out the reality of the situation to his daughter, explaining that their stepfamily provides for them daily. He wants the kids to appreciate what they have but is upset that they still idolize the mother who isn't there most of the time.

So, is he in the wrong? Well, he's not outright saying negative things about the mother, just highlighting the contrast between the mother's limited role and the stepfamily's full-time care. He's also not forcing the daughter to criticize her mother; he's just explaining the situation. The key here is that he's trying to help the daughter understand the context without personally attacking her mother. 

But maybe he's being a bit harsh? He's making a comparison that could make the daughter feel conflicted. However, his intent is to help her recognize the stepfamily's efforts. Also, the mother's actions (affairs, jail, etc.) are part of the reality, and the user is pointing out the practical aspects of being a parent full-time versus part-time. 

The user is in a tough position because he wants the kids to have a positive view of their mother but also wants them to acknowledge the support they get from him and his wife. He's not forcing the daughter to say something, just guiding her. It seems like he's trying to balance between protecting the mother's image and expressing his own frustrations. 

I think the answer is B (No), because he's not directly attacking the mother but explaining the situation. He's trying to help his daughter make an informed choice rather than blindly idolizing her mother. While there's a valid concern about the daughter's perception, the user's approach isn't malicious. He's being honest about the circumstances without being cruel. So, he's not in the wrong here.
